body: @YanivO1123 your labels are incorrect. YOLOv5 will train on the exact boxes shown in train_batch*.jpg, that's the entire purpose of displaying these images to you.

@YanivO1123 see **Train Custom Data** tutorial for instructions on getting started:

## YOLOv5 Tutorials

* [Train Custom Data](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5/wiki/Train-Custom-Data)  üöÄ RECOMMENDED
* [Tips for Best Training Results](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5/wiki/Tips-for-Best-Training-Results)  ‚òòÔ∏è RECOMMENDED
* [Weights & Biases Logging](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5/issues/1289)  üåü NEW
* [Supervisely Ecosystem](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5/issues/2518)  üåü NEW
* [Multi-GPU Training](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5/issues/475)
* [PyTorch Hub](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5/issues/36)  ‚≠ê NEW
* [TorchScript, ONNX, CoreML Export](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5/issues/251) üöÄ
* [Test-Time Augmentation (TTA)](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5/issues/303)
* [Model Ensembling](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5/issues/318)
* [Model Pruning/Sparsity](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5/issues/304)
* [Hyperparameter Evolution](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5/issues/607)
* [Transfer Learning with Frozen Layers](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5/issues/1314)  ‚≠ê NEW
* [TensorRT Deployment](https://github.com/wang-xinyu/tensorrtx)

@glenn-jocher Thanks!
I've recloned, and re-set all the data directories. It now appears to load the (same) given bounding boxes correctly. We must have mis-changed some configuration. 

However, I am now getting the following error / warning message:
"Image sizes do not match. This will cause images to be display incorrectly in the UI."
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33690998/120783909-2edae200-c534-11eb-81da-c2eed9660472.png)

The images are of different sizes, none square, from 220ish all the way to 500ish. Im passing --image-size 416.
Is that a problem? Am I mis-using the configuration? Do I need to preprocess my images to set them all the be square / same sizes / fitting the 416?

@YanivO1123 this is a matplotlib warning produced when plotting labels.jpg sometimes, I'm not entirely sure of the cause, but it is not related to training at all.

If you find the exact line that causes this perhaps we can run it with warning disabled, because a number of people have asked about this message.

@glenn-jocher thanks again! In other words, there shouldn't be any problems using the repo / calling train with images of different sizes, and the --image-size argument being called with a  different size than the images, correct? There is no need to manually resize the dataset images or anything?

For future reference if other users experience the same bounding boxes appearing misaligned (I saw some issues that were closed due to being stale without the users mentioning their fix), I suspect our problem was caused by refactoring directory names resulting in conflicts with the is_coco variable, being set to true when it shouldn't have.
@YanivO1123 you can train with any size or shape images, there are no constraints. No manual resizing of any kind is required.

@YanivO1123 I'm trying to reproduce the warning you saw so that I can suppress it, but I can't reproduce it at any --img-size with the COCO128 training in our colab notebook. Can you isolate the source for me, or can you provide a minimum reproducible example? (directions below). Thanks!
```
"Image sizes do not match. This will cause images to be display incorrectly in the UI."
```

üëã hi, thanks for letting us know about this problem with YOLOv5 üöÄ. We've created a few short guidelines below to help users provide what we need in order to get started investigating a possible problem.

## How to create a Minimal, Reproducible Example

When asking a question, people will be better able to provide help if you provide **code** that they can easily understand and use to **reproduce** the problem. This is referred to by community members as creating a [minimum reproducible example](https://stackoverflow.com/help/minimal-reproducible-example). Your code that reproduces the problem should be:

* ‚úÖ **Minimal** ‚Äì Use as little code as possible that still produces the same problem
* ‚úÖ **Complete** ‚Äì Provide **all** parts someone else needs to reproduce your problem in the question itself
* ‚úÖ **Reproducible** ‚Äì Test the code you're about to provide to make sure it reproduces the problem

In addition to the above requirements, for [Ultralytics](https://ultralytics.com/) to provide assistance your code should be:

* ‚úÖ **Current** ‚Äì Verify that your code is up-to-date with current GitHub [master](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5/tree/master), and if necessary `git pull` or `git clone` a new copy to ensure your problem has not already been resolved by previous commits.
* ‚úÖ **Unmodified** ‚Äì Your problem must be reproducible without any modifications to the codebase in this repository. [Ultralytics](https://ultralytics.com/) does not provide support for custom code ‚ö†Ô∏è.

If you believe your problem meets all of the above criteria, please close this issue and raise a new one using the üêõ **Bug Report** [template](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5/issues/new/choose) and providing a [minimum reproducible example](https://stackoverflow.com/help/minimal-reproducible-example) to help us better understand and diagnose your problem. 

Thank you! üòÉ
@YanivO1123 BTW the script-tracing warning has now been suppressed in https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5/pull/3454.

@glenn-jocher thanks! I'm working from this repo though (yolov3). Better I clone and run my training from yolov5?
Also, from the last message I understand that code for reproduction is not necessary anymore, correct?
